title: Does a writ of execution order need to be signed by a judge in the state of California in order to be enforced???
question: My friend was recently involved in a lawsuit and now has a judgement attached to her name. To make matters worse a sheriff showed up at her door with some kind of order to seize property that she did not have. After further investigation it seems that the writ of exexcution was never signed by a judge. Is normal? So my question is......
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Judgment lien,Debt,Wage garnishment,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Filing a lawsuit,Summons and complaint
answers: The Writ of Execution is not signed by a judge. What the judge signs is the Judgment. Was there a trial at which your friend appeared and presented evidence? Was there a stipulation to enter a judgment against your friend? Was your friend properly served with a copy of the Summons and Complaint? Your friend should gather the litigation documents and consult a lawyer for advise as to her legal rights and remedies.
No, the writ of execution is issued by the clerk of the court. A judge does not need to sign it.
The clerk of court, not the judge, issues the writ of execution.
